issues.text: whether, assuming that the Bihar Private Forests Act, 1946 and 1948 were valid, the proceedings under Chapter III of the Act for declaring the village of Jun as a private protected forest were legal

anchor.surface_text: We consider that it will be convenient to deal first with the point as to whether, assuming that the Bihar Private Forests Act, 1946 and 1948 were valid, the proceedings under Chapter III of the Act for declaring the village of Jun as a private protected forest were legal before considering the question as to the constitutionality of the Act raised by the additional grounds urged before us.

issues.text: whether the notification under s. 14 did contravene the statute on account of omission of the name of the Manjhis

anchor.surface_text: the principal point urged for impugning the validity of the proceedings under Ch. III of the Act was that the Manjhis, whose name had been entered in the record of rights as the land-holders of the suit-village of Jun had not been set out in the notification published under s. 14 of the Act

issues.text: whether the notification which was legal under s. 14, had been properly served on the interested persons as required by the provisions of Ch. III

anchor.surface_text: The next question that arises is whether the notification which was legal under s. 14, had been properly served on the interested persons as required by the provisions of Ch. III.

issues.text: that the Bihar Private Forests Acts of 1946 and 1948 were beyond the competence of the Provincial Government-not being within the legislative entries in the Provincial Legislative List in Sch. VII of the Government of India Act, 1935

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the appellant formulated three points in support of his plea regarding the invalidity of the impugned enactment and its application to the petitioner 1 that the Bihar Private Forests Acts of 1946 and 1948 were beyond the competence of the Provincial Government-not being within the legislative entries in the Provincial Legislative List in Sch. VII of the Government of India Act, 1935,

issues.text: that even if the legislation was competent in the sense of being covered by the entries in the List, the same was unconstitutional as being in contravention of the constitutional requirements of s. 299(2) of the same Act

anchor.surface_text: 2 that even if the legislation was competent in the sense of being covered by the entries in the List, the same was unconstitutional as being in contravention of the constitutional requirements of s. 299(2) of the same Act,

issues.text: that even if the legislation were competent and also constitutionally valid under the Government of India Act, 1935, its provisions could not be enforced against the petitioner after the Constitution came into force on January 26, 1950, as the provisions of the enactment contravened Arts. 19(1)(f) and 31(2) of the Constitution

issues.text: whether the impugned enactments violate s. 299(2) of the Government of India Act, 1935

anchor.surface_text: The next submission to be considered is whether the impugned -enactments violate s. 299(2) of the Government of India Act, 1935.

arguments.claim: Notifications under s.14 invalid due to omission of Manjhis' name as landlord

anchor.surface_text: The learned Subordinate Judge who tried the suit, though he held the Act valid, accepted the plaintiffs contention that the notifications issued under s. 14 and the other provisions of Chapter III of the Act were invalid, primarily for the reason that the name of the Manjhis as the landlord had not been mentioned in the notification issued under s. 14 and on this ground he passed a decree directing the State to restore possession of the forest to the plaintiff so as to enable him to enjoy the same for a substituted period making allowance for the 7-1/2 months for which he had worked the jungle before his enjoyment was interfered in October 1946.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: legal proceeding whatsoever, lie in any Court of law against any servant of the crown for or on account of or in respect of any such proceeding or ac

arguments.court_reasoning: s.14 does not require name of landlord; emphasis on land identity; ordinary rule of construction makes listed requirements exhaustive

arguments.claim: s.14 notification invalid because Manjhis not named despite being landlords per record of rights

anchor.surface_text: As would have been noticed even from the narration of the facts, the principal point urged for impugning the validity of the proceedings under Ch. III of the Act was that the Manjhis, whose name had been entered in the record of rights as the land-holders of the suit-village of Jun had not been set out in the notification published under s. 14 of the Act and this was the ground upon which the learned Subordinate Judge decided the suit in favour of the appellant.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: legal proceeding whatsoever, lie in any Court of law against any servant of the crown for or on account of or in respect of any such proceeding or ac

arguments.court_reasoning: No express requirement for landlord's name in s.14; sufficient to describe land; purpose is to notify land identity

arguments.claim: Omission of Manjhis' name does not invalidate notification

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges reversed the decree of the Subordinate Judge and dismissed the suit with costs, holding that the omission of the name of the Manjhis in the notification issued on October 14, 1946, did not render the same invalid and that even otherwise the proceedings under Ch. III of the Act had been validated by s. 2 of Act XII of 1949 to whose terms we shall refer in due course.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: legal proceeding whatsoever, lie in any Court of law against any servant of the crown for or on account of or in respect of any such proceeding or ac

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed; name not essential requirement of s.14

arguments.claim: Service of s.14 notices invalid as rules for prescribed manner framed after notification (Oct 21, 1946)

anchor.surface_text: The principal point that was urged to call in question the validity of the service of the notifications was based on the fact that the notices had to be served under the terms of s. 14 in the prescribed manner and that the rules which prescribed the manner of service were framed and issued only on October 21, 1946, with the result that any service of notice effected before that date could not be deemed to be a proper service or a service in accordance with the rules and therefore of the statute.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore clearly of the opinion that the learned Judges of the High Court were right in holding that the notification under s. 14 did not contravene the statute.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the High Court, on the other hand, held and, in our opinion, correctly, that the effect of the failure to serve notices or any informality in the service of the notices required by s. 14 and succeeding sections of the Act was rectified and validated by the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that the impugned enactments were validly enacted and are not obnoxious to the provisions of the Government of India Act, 1935.

arguments.claim: Appellant merely licensee/contractor, not lessee; rights extinguished under s.22 with compensation

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary to state at the outset, that under the deeds dated February 23, 1946 and March 15, 1946, the status of the appellant quod the Manjhis is only that of a licensee or contractor having the right to cut and remove the trees etc. and not that of a lessee.

arguments.claim: Bihar Acts analogous to Estates Management Act in Kameshwar Singh, hence invalid

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the appellant formulated three points... based on the reasoning contained in the judgment of a Special Bench of the Patna High Court in M. D. Kameshwar Singh v. State of Bihar where the learned Judges held the Bihar State Management of Estates and Tenures Act, 1949, to be ultra vires

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e companysidered was a post-Constitution enactment  Act XXVIII of 1950 dated April 10, 1950  which replaced an Ordinance issued in January, 1950. The

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguished; forests specific entry unlike estates; prior practice under Indian Forests Act

arguments.claim: Patna HC previously upheld validity of Acts distinguishing Kameshwar Singh

anchor.surface_text: Before entering on a discussion of the points urged we should add that the constitutional validity of the Acts impugned has been the subject of decision of the Patna High Court on two occasions and these judgments are reported in Sm. Khemi Mahatani v. Charan Napit, and B.N. Singh v. State. In both of them the learned Judges of the High Court have distinguished the decision in Kameshwar Singh v. State of Bihar and have upheld the validity of the Acts impugned.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e companysidered was a post-Constitution enactment  Act XXVIII of 1950 dated April 10, 1950  which replaced an Ordinance issued in January, 1950. The

arguments.claim: Rights under deeds entitle plaintiff to declaration unaffected by Acts; damages; possession; mesne profits

anchor.surface_text: Having failed in these proceedings under the Act, the appellant filed the suit which has given rise to the present appeal T. S. 1 of 1952 in the Court of the Subordinate Judge of Daltonganj impleading the State of Bihar and one A. R. Chaudhuri to whom the right to cut and collect bamboo and timber in a portion of the area covered by the appellants contract was granted by the Government, as the second defen- dant.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: n under Ch. III of the Act, including the numberification issued under s. 14 were valid and in accordance with the law and that if the Bihar Private F

arguments.court_reasoning: Proceedings valid if Act valid; Act valid

holdings.text: The notification under s. 14 did not contravene the statute despite the omission of the name of the Manjhis.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore clearly of the opinion that the learned Judges of the High Court were right in holding that the notification under s. 14 did not contravene the statute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 14 specifies contents exhaustively; no requirement to name landlord; emphasis on land identity via description; purpose to notify land, not owner; service on correct landlord would cure anyway.

holdings.text: The proceedings under Chapter III including the notification under s.14 were valid due to the Bihar Private Forests (Validating) Act, Act XII of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the High Court, on the other hand, held and, in our opinion, correctly, that the effect of the failure to serve notices or any informality in the service of the notices required by s. 14 and succeeding sections of the Act was rectified and validated by the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 2 of Validating Act explicitly deems proceedings under ss.15,21,29 valid despite defects in s.14 notice service on landlord.

holdings.text: Proceedings under Ch.III valid and suit properly dismissed assuming Act valid.

anchor.surface_text: In agreement with the learned Judges of the High Court we hold that the proceedings taken under Ch. III of the Act, including the notification issued under s. 14 were valid and in accordance with the law and that if the Bihar Private Forests Act were valid the plaintiff could have no legal ground of complaint which he could agitate in the suit and that the suit was therefore properly directed to be dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Combines valid notification and validated service; no grounds for suit if Act constitutional.

holdings.text: Bihar Private Forests Acts 1946 and 1948 within provincial legislative competence under Entry 22 'Forests'.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the item Forests would permit all and every legislation which in pith and substance, to use a phrase familiar in this branch of the law, was on the subject of forests. It is not possible to argue that the two Acts here impugned do not satisfy this test.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pith and substance is forests; covers management/control of private forests; analogous to Indian Forests Act 1927 Ch.V; legislative history and policy support.

holdings.text: Impugned enactments do not violate s.299(2) GOI Act 1935; vesting management/control not 'acquisition'.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that the impugned enactments were validly enacted and are not obnoxious to the provisions of the Government of India Act, 1935.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Acquisition requires transfer of title/ownership; management vesting is regulatory, not depriving ownership bundle; incidents like possession not separate property; compensation for contractors provided; follows Belfast Corp., distinguishes requisition cases.

holdings.text: No violation of Arts.19(1)(f), 31(2) post-Constitution as rights extinguished pre-1950 by valid law.

anchor.surface_text: We have held that the legislation under which the appellants rights were extinguished, subject to his claim for compensation, was a valid law. It would therefore follow that the appellant could have no rights which could survive the Constitution so as to enable him to invoke the protection of Part III thereof.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contractor rights terminated in 1946 by valid s.22 with compensation; no surviving rights post-26.1.1950 to claim fundamental rights protection; distinguishes continuing deprivations.

holdings.text: Appellant holds status of licensee or contractor under deeds, not lessee.

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary to state at the outset, that under the deeds dated February 23, 1946 and March 15, 1946, the status of the appellant quod the Manjhis is only that of a licensee or contractor having the right to cut and remove the trees etc. and not that of a lessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on terms of deeds granting right to cut/remove, not transfer of possession/lease.

precedents.citation: M. D. Kameshwar Singh v. State of Bihar  1

anchor.surface_text: M. D. Kameshwar Singh v. State of Bihar  1  where the learned Judges held the Bihar State Management of Estates and Tenures Act, 1949, to be ultra vires of the powers of the Provincial Legislature as contained in the Government of India Act, 1935.

precedents.case_name: M. D. Kameshwar Singh v. State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: Bihar State Management of Estates and Tenures Act, 1949, ultra vires powers of Provincial Legislature under Government of India Act, 1935
precedents.cited_holding: Act beyond legislative competence and violates s. 299(2)

precedents.citation: Sm. Khemi Mahatani v. Charan Napit  1

anchor.surface_text: Sm. Khemi Mahatani v. Charan Napit  1 , and B.N. Singh v. State  2 . In both of them the learned Judges of the High Court have distinguished the decision in Kameshwar Singh v. State of Bihar  3 and have upheld the validity of the Acts now impugned.

anchor.surface_text: In agreement with the learned Judges of the High Court we hold that the proceedings taken under Ch. III of the Act, including the notification issued under s. 14 were valid and in accordance with the law and that if the Bihar Private Forests Act were valid the plaintiff could have no legal ground of complaint which he could agitate in the suit and that the suit was therefore properly directed to be dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: Suit properly dismissed; proceedings under Chapter III valid; Bihar Private Forests Acts of 1946 and 1948 constitutionally valid under Government of India Act, 1935; no violation of fundamental rights post-Constitution; no declaration of rights, possession, damages or mesne profits to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the item Forests would permit all and every legislation which in pith and substance, to use a phrase familiar in this branch of the law, was on the subject of forests. It is not possible to argue that the two Acts here impugned do not satisfy this test.

In agreement with the learned Judges of the High Court we hold that the proceedings taken under Ch. III of the Act, including the notification issued under s. 14 were valid and in accordance with the law and that if the Bihar Private Forests Act were valid the plaintiff could have no legal ground of complaint which he could agitate in the suit and that the suit was therefore properly directed to be dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: We have held that the legislation under which the appellants rights were extinguished, subject to his claim for compensation, was a valid law. It would therefore follow that the appellant could have no rights which could survive the Constitution so as to enable him to invoke the protection of Part III thereof.

In agreement with the learned Judges of the High Court we hold that the proceedings taken under Ch. III of the Act, including the notification issued under s. 14 were valid and in accordance with the law and that if the Bihar Private Forests Act were valid the plaintiff could have no legal ground of complaint which he could agitate in the suit and that the suit was therefore properly directed to be dismissed.
